citation.article-title: Analysis of 16S rRNA and methane monooxygenase gene sequences reveals a novel group of thermotolerant and thermophilic methanotrophs, Methylocaldum gen. nov.

p.s: Description of Methylocaldum szegediense sp. nov.
Methylocaldum szegediense (sze.ged.i.en.se (Szeged Hungarian n., town of Szeged; szegediense M.L.adj., from the town of Szeged))
The characteristics are the same as the characteristics given in the genus description above, but include the following traits.
Cells are 0.6–1.0x1.0–1.5 μm.
Pronounced pleomorphism appears in the stationary phase of growth.
Motility appears at some stages of growth.
Chain formation may occur in late exponential phase.
Nondiffusible brown pigments are produced to differing extents in later stages of growth (light to dark brown).
One-week-old colonies are mucoid or cartilaginous, buff to light brown.
Upon prolonged growth, colonies turn dark brown.
Colonies may be polymorphic; either shiny, smooth-surfaced with entire margins or dry, rough-surfaced with irregular margins.
Sensitive to desiccation.
Extracellular polymeric substance is produced in liquid culture.
Temperature range of growth is 37–62° C.
Optimal growth temperature is 55° C.
No growth occurs above 62° C.
Growth on other one-carbon (C1) substrates is limited: no growth observed on methanol, formate, formamide or methylamine.
N2 is not fixed.
Resistant to heating at 80°C.
G+C content is 57 mol%.

The type strain is OR2, which has been isolated from a greenhouse heating system fed directly from a hot spring connected to a natural gas field near Szeged, Hungary, and has been deposited in the NCIMB.
